textBeforeTable: The precise positions of the Moon and Jupiter at the moment of closest approach will be as follows: The pair will be too widely separated to fit within the field of view of a telescope, but will be visible to the naked eye or through a pair of binoculars. At the moment of closest approach, the Moon will be at mag -12.5, and Jupiter at mag -2.7, both in the constellation Gemini. From Ashburn (click to change), the pair will be visible in the morning sky. They will become accessible at around 18:57, when they rise 7° above your north-eastern horizon. They will then reach its highest point in the sky at 01:33, 73° above your southern horizon. They will be lost to dawn twilight at around 07:02, 20° above your western horizon. The Moon and Jupiter will make a close approach, passing within 4°55' of each other. textAfterTable: The coordinates above are given in J2000.0. The pair will be at an angular separation of 159° from the Sun, which is in Sagittarius at this time of year. The sky on 19 December 2013 Sunrise: 07:23 Sunset: 16:49 Twilight from 05:47 until 18:25 All times shown in EST. Age of Moon: 16 days Rise Culm. Set Mercury 07:04 11:42 16:21 Venus 09:27 14:19 19:11 Moon 19:23 01:32 08:34 Mars 00:39 06:40 12:42 Jupiter 18:08 01:33 08:55 Saturn 04:13 09:25 14:36 Source The circumstances of this event were computed from the DE405 ephemeris published by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL).
